speaker: Amit Varma
message: I.V.M On December 2, 1977, two men walked out to the center of a cricket field to toss a coin. The venue was a VFL park in Melbourne, which had a capacity of 80,000 people. And yet there were only 500 spectators in this large ground. There was just one in-house photographer to record the moment. At the toss, when the coin finally hit the ground, you could probably have heard it in that silent, empty stadium. This was a match that was not recognized by the ICC, a match with few spectators. And yet it was the legend Garfield Sobers who was supervising the toss, and the two captains were Ian Chappell and Clive Lloyd. This was a day that cricket changed forever.

message: I do think it was a bit of a perfect storm. It was a very unusual concatenation of circumstances in 1977. A, you had a game that was very, very popular, and there's no doubt about it. You had the rights for – the commercial and broadcasting rights for that cricket were being significantly undersold. They were basically in the hands of a national broadcaster that broadcast the game essentially on a kind of a grace and favor basis, I guess in much the same way as Doordarshan had in India forever and a day. The important figures in World Series cricket are not simply Kerry Packer and the players, but there are people like John Cornell and Austin Robertson and Paul Hogan who played such an important part in bringing the players and Packer as an impresario together. I think that where Packer had a unique advantage was that he was quite a young man. He's only 39 in 1977. He's trying to make his own way in the world out from under the influence or the reputation of his late father who had been a great press baron, Sir Frank, in his own right. He was looking not necessarily to make his name, but to create something of his own. And he'd already revolutionised the magazine market in Australia by setting up the first really significant sort of new wave women's magazine, Clio. And he was fascinated by sport, the potential of sport to create lots of content throughout the year, relatively cheap to produce, embroidered with natural ad breaks, which naturally captured the nation's imagination. I don't think any single individual, with the possible exception of Rupert Murdoch in Australia, could have had quite the same grand conception about the role of sport as a kind of a commercial battering ram. speaker: Guest 2
message: It is an interesting question. I have asked Mike this directly. I said that when you were playing the game, there was no batting coach in the England set-up. How do you think he would have used a batting coach? Do you think it would have made you any better player? His answer was actually quite a thoughtful one. He said that towards the end of his career, he had begun sort of fiddling almost compulsively with his tip-net, partly because of his bad back, just to feel more comfortable with the crease. He said the most valuable coaching advice that he ever received was just the reinforcement not to make changes, just to rely on doing things simply to have faith in yourself, that degree of reinforcement. It's interesting that a man as psychologically strong as Mike would have required that degree of reinforcement, but that was something that he did feel that he'd missed out on. Mike loved the batting. Mike loved resistance, since that is quite an old-fashioned quality these days. Players want to lead the game. Players want to take the aggressive role. Mike loved to withstand, and at his best, there was probably no one better. I suspect that withstanding is something that's kind of enduring, like a rock in the face of erosion is something that's kind of going by the board, because there is this constant accent on enterprise, on taking control of the game, of forcing the game, imposing your will

speaker: Amit Varma
message: and imposing your momentum. And to be fair, in the shorter form of the game, aggression is just more positive. speaker: Guest 2
message: to get me, I'm just going to try and hit him out of the attack. Peterson said, interestingly, that at least that demonstrated a positive mindset, that even if he was getting into position to play aggressive shots, even if he didn't actually play them, you're naturally a better player if you're thinking positive thoughts. Even if you don't actually attack, at least thinking of attack puts you into better shapes and makes you more resilient under those circumstances.

It humbles you before it constantly, just at that very moment where you think you've got it mastered, it turns around and bites you in the bum.
